comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: On April 29, 1914, Upton Sinclair was arrested in New York for parading in front of the office of Standard Oil See news.google.com/newspapers?id=LhRHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=F3sMA... and NYT of April 30, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E0CE2DE153DE733A... so this is related to:

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
Another 1914 Bain/LOC photo of Upton Sinclair in New York City:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5169602906/]

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: I think so.  Sinclair is the right-hand guy in the light suit, judging from the Wikipedia page.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The photo was taken in front of the Tombs prison court, where Upton Sinclair was arraigned and briefly incarcerated.

comment.author: 60894293@N00
comment._content: An article on April 29th said he was wearing crepe on his left arm, what was considered the proper wearing for mourning. The demonstration was in support of Colorado coal miners to whom John D. Rockefeller, Jr., would not listen.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The day book. (Chicago, Ill.) 1911-1917, June 01, 1914, LAST EDITION, Image 7 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045487/1914-06-01/ed-... has a summary of a letter Sinclair wrote to Rockefeller a few days earlier.
